question.body: Sweat produced by apocrine sweat glands contains water, salt, and other solutes. When most people think about sweating, they think about smelling bad. Sweat itself, however, does not smell, so why do people smell bad after they have been sweating?

multiple_choice.choice: Sweat contains a microbe-killing compound that creates this odor.
Microbes on your skin break down fats and create this odor.
The salt interacts with chemicals on your skin and creates this odor.
Merocrine glands secrete other things besides sweat that creates this odor.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Eccrine glands secrete a microbe-killing compound, but it is the sweat from apocrine glands that is typically associated with odor.
Correct. Microbes live on your skin and when they break down the fats in the apocrine secretions that mix with sweat, waste is created, and it has an odor.
Incorrect.The salt does not interact to produce any odor; in fact, it may be antibacterial and help reduce the odor.
Incorrect. Eccrine glands secrete sweat for regulating body temperature; apocrine glands secrete the fatty acids that bacteria metabolize.

part.hint: Apocrine glands become active during puberty and secrete a sweat with more fatty acids.
